Migration.Name: Add FTU Tolerance Type reference and field

PO.Data: The mainenance schedule follows the schedule requirement regardless of the tolerance.
The mainenance schedule follows the schedule requirement regardless of the tolerance.

Data.oldValue: The mainenance schedule follows the schedule requirement regardless of the tolerance.

PO.Data: The mainenance schedule follows the schedule requirement regardless of the tolerance used.
The next operation will be schedule from the last completed operation.
The next operation will be schedule from the last completed operation.

Data.oldValue: The mainenance schedule follows the schedule requirement regardless of the tolerance used.

PO.Data: The next mainenance operation will be scheduled without consideration of the tolerance applied or when the last operation was actually carried out.

Data.oldValue: The next operation will be schedule from the last completed operation.

PO.Data: The next operation will be schedule from the release date/usage (return to service).

Data.oldValue: The next mainenance operation will be scheduled without consideration of the tolerance applied or when the last operation was actually carried out.

PO.Data: The next mainenance operation will be scheduled based on the original due date/usage.

Data.oldValue: The next operation will be schedule from the release date/usage (return to service).

PO.Data: The next operation will be schedule from the release date/usage (return to service). This may include the previous tolerance used.

Data.oldValue: The next mainenance operation will be scheduled based on the original due date/usage.

PO.Data: The next mainenance operation will be scheduled based on the original due date/usage. This ignores the use of the tolerance.

Data.oldValue: The next operation will be schedule from the release date/usage (return to service). This may include the previous tolerance used.

PO.Data: The next operation will be schedule from the release date/usage (return to service). This will include the previous tolerance if used.

The next scheduled action will be based on the earlier of the previous schedule or the date/usage of the last completed operation. Ignores tolerance extensions and advances the schedule if work is done early.

The next scheduled action will be based on the earlier of the previous schedule or the date/usage of the last completed operation. Ignores tolerance extensions and advances the schedule if work is done early.

Data.oldValue: Not Extended

PO.Data: Determines if the tolerance on a maintenance schedule/requirement is cumulative or fixed.
Determines if the tolerance on a maintenance schedule/requirement is cumulative or fixed.

Data.oldValue: Maintenance Schedule ID
Maintenance schedules

PO.Data:
In certain circumstances, a maintenance schedule can have a tolerance where the maintenance activity can be performed within a range of time and still meet regulatory requirements. These tolerances fall into three categories:
  • Fixed - the use of a tolerance is ignored and the date/usage of the next scheduled maintenance action is based on the previously scheduled date/usage. In this case, if the operation is scheduled for every 200 hours with a 10 hour tolerance and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would remain scheduled for 400 hours.
  • Cummulative - the date/usage of the next next scheduled maintenance action is based on the last release to service. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 405 hours. If the last was completed early at 195 hours, the next would be scheduled at 395 hours.
  • Not Extended - in this case, maintenance is scheduled from the eariler of the last operation or the last scheduled date/usage. In other words, if the mainenance is performed early, the next schedule will be early. If the tolerance is late, the next schedule will not be extended. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 400 hours. If the last was completed early at 195 hours, the next would be scheduled at 395 hours.

Data.oldValue: Determines if the tolerance on a maintenance schedule/requirement is cumulative or fixed.

PO.Data: Determines how the next time/usage based scheduled maintenance requirement is determined.

In certain circumstances, a maintenance schedule can have a tolerance where the maintenance activity can be performed within a range of time and still meet regulatory requirements. These tolerances fall into three categories:
  • Fixed - the use of a tolerance is ignored and the date/usage of the next scheduled maintenance action is based on the previously scheduled date/usage. In this case, if the operation is scheduled for every 200 hours with a 10 hour tolerance and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would remain scheduled for 400 hours.
  • Cummulative - the date/usage of the next next scheduled maintenance action is based on the last release to service. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 405 hours. If the last was completed early at 195 hours, the next would be scheduled at 395 hours.
  • Not Extended - in this case, maintenance is scheduled from the eariler of the last operation or the last scheduled date/usage. In other words, if the mainenance is performed early, the next schedule will be early. If the tolerance is late, the next schedule will not be extended. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 400 hours. If the last was completed early at 195 hours, the next would be scheduled at 395 hours.
Determines how the next date based scheduled maintenance requirement is determined.

In this case, if the operation is scheduled for every 200 hours with a 10 hour tolerance and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would remain scheduled for 400 hours.
  • Cummulative - the date/usage of the next next scheduled maintenance action is based on the last release to service. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 405 hours.   • Not Extended - in this case, maintenance is scheduled from the eariler of the last operation or the last scheduled date/usage. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 400 hours. If the last was completed early at 195 hours, the next would be scheduled at 395 hours.
Determines how the next date based scheduled maintenance requirement is determined.
Determines how the next time/usage based scheduled maintenance requirement is determined.

  • Fixed - the use of a tolerance is ignored and the date/usage of the next scheduled maintenance action is based on the previously scheduled date/usage. PO.Data: Determines how the next time/date based scheduled maintenance requirement is determined.

Data.oldValue: Tolerance Type

PO.Data: The time interval is part of the action compliance and determines the limits on the initial or repetitive action in terms of the interval of time regardless of the usage of the component.
The time interval limit for the action. Leave blank/null for no time limit. UOM is standard, typically days. Set programmatically.
The time interval is part of the action compliance and determines the limits on the initial or repetitive action in terms of the interval of time regardless of the usage of the component.
The time interval limit for the action. Leave blank/null for no time limit. UOM is standard, typically days. Set programmatically.

The maintenance requirement Time Interval defines when the maintenance action associated with the requirement has to be performed. The Time Interval Tolerance provides the +/- limits on the actual maintenance.
The Tolerance in the Time Interval in the same units as the Interval

The maintenance requirement Time Interval defines when the maintenance action associated with the requirement has to be performed. The Time Interval Tolerance provides the +/- limits on the actual maintenance.
The Tolerance in the Time Interval in the same units as the Interval

In certain circumstances, a maintenance schedule can have a tolerance where the maintenance activity can be performed within a range of time and still meet regulatory requirements. These tolerances fall into three categories:
  • Fixed - the use of a tolerance is ignored and the date/usage of the next scheduled maintenance action is based on the previously scheduled date/usage. In this case, if the operation is scheduled for every 200 hours with a 10 hour tolerance and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would remain scheduled for 400 hours.
  • Cummulative - the date/usage of the next next scheduled maintenance action is based on the last release to service. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 405 hours. If the last was completed early at 195 hours, the next would be scheduled at 395 hours.
  • Not Extended - in this case, maintenance is scheduled from the eariler of the last operation or the last scheduled date/usage. In other words, if the mainenance is performed early, the next schedule will be early. If the tolerance is late, the next schedule will not be extended. Here, if the schedule was for 200 hours and the last was completed at 205 hours, the next would be scheduled for 400 hours. If the last was completed early at 195 hours, the next would be scheduled at 395 hours.
Determines how the next time/date based scheduled maintenance requirement is determined.

Determines how the next time/date based scheduled maintenance requirement is determined.
The usage interval is part of the action compliance and determines the limits on the initial or repetitive action in terms of the interval of component life usage also known as Time in Service.
The usage or Time in Service (TIS) interval limit for the action. Uses standard Unit of Measure - typically hours.
The usage interval is part of the action compliance and determines the limits on the initial or repetitive action in terms of the interval of component life usage also known as Time in Service.
The usage or Time in Service (TIS) interval limit for the action. Uses standard Unit of Measure - typically hours.

The maintenance requirement Usage Interval defines when the maintenance action associated with the requirement has to be performed. The Usage Interval Tolerance provides the +/- limits on the actual maintenance.
The Tolerance in the Usage Interval in the same units as the Usage Interval

The maintenance requirement Usage Interval defines when the maintenance action associated with the requirement has to be performed. The Usage Interval Tolerance provides the +/- limits on the actual maintenance.
The Tolerance in the Usage Interval in the same units as the Usage Interval
